title: Leaves from the journal of our life in the Highlands, from 1848 to 1861 :
author: Victoria
snippet: We saw the splendid scenery to such greatadvantage on both sides : Ben Lawers, with smallwaterfalls descending its sides, amid other highmountains wooded here and there ; with Kenmorein the distance ; the view, looking back, as the lochwinds, was most beautiful.

title: Guy Mannering, or, The astrologer /
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: — They live, Mr Mannering,  by the shore-side, at Annan, and a more decent orderly couple, with six as fme bairns as you would wish to see plash in a salt-water duh; and little eurlie Godfrey  — that's the eldest, the come o' will, as I may say — he's on board an excise yacht — I hae a cousin at the board of excise, that's Commissioner Bertram ; he got his commissionership in the great contest for the county, that ye must have heard of, for it was appealed to the House of Commons  — now I should have voted there for the Laird of Balruddery ; but ye see my father was a Jacobite, and out whh Kenmore,  so he never took the oaths ; and I

title: Memoirs of the life of Sir Walter Scott,
author: Lockhart, J. G.
snippet: My present employment is watching, from time to time, the progress  of a stupid cause, in order to be ready to reduce the sentence into writing, when the Court shall have decided whether Gordon of Kenmore or MacMichan of Meikleforth head be the superior of the lands of Tarschrechan and Dal- brattie, and entitled to the feudal casualties payable forth thereof, which may amount to twopence sterling, once in half- a-dozen of years.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Yet as well, or better almost, do I love the Larg of Kenmore, where still dwell, in their green age and unseared leaf, Sholto and Maud together.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But since he had spoken thus at the Larg of Kenmore, and nothing had come of it, I confess that I paid no great heed to his words.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: I was wi' them at the Larg o' Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: We rode poorly and unattended, both because that would be better pleasing  to the King, who loved not arrays of folk riding hither and thither athwart his kingdom, and also because unless we had taken the herds from the hills, there were no other retinue about the Larg of Kenmore save only Sholto hirpling on his crutch.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: And to his brothers, Laurence and Herries, Sholto said kindlv, " There is little enough for you to get here, lads, on the rough side o' the Larg o' Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: He had looked with his usual contempt at the work which had been done during his absence at the Larg of Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: It was on the third day of the stay of Malise the Smith at the house of the Larg of Kenmore that there came a message  from the King, at StirHng, commanding with all urgence the armourer's presence at Carron Straths, where the great new cannons were being made under Laurence's care.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Surely never grimmer wolf glared at sheepfold, than the brain-clouded Smith of Carlinwark upon the Larg of Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: I heard the click of the yett, with which at night Donald barred in Sholto's scanty stock of bestial — for there were still wolves a-many in the fastnesses of Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: But was I not speaking of the Larg of Kenmore, round which the heather ringed itself, and at whose very doorstep  the whaups and wild moor-fowl cried suddenly in, making the bairns laugh at their meals ?

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: Yet, because in the course of this history I have had much to tell of these still places, where the crying of a bird or a change in the wind is a subject for an hour's converse, and the new moon seen over the right shoulder an occasion of festival, I shall say little about the Larg of Kenmore.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: The Larg of Kenmore was a place in which one might well be content to grow old.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: So, adieus being said, through the pleasant fields and fringing woods we betook us to Kenmore, Maud keeping close to Sholto that she might watch his face, causing him to get off and rest as often as she discovered a trace of fatigue.

title: May Margaret,
author: Crockett, S. R.
snippet: So he had given the little tower called the Larg of Kenmore upon Tayside to Sholto to dwell in, and (said he) " If your Lady Margaret is waxen weary of her nunneries and mummeries, let her also go thither and keep the bairnies' frocks in order.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: I told you, that in the midst of the 6torm, on the wilds of Kenmore, Burns was rapt in meditation.

snippet: " We left Kenmore, and went to Gatehouse, I took him the moor-road, where savage and desolate regions extended wide around.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: In short, I can scarcely conceive a scene more terribly  romantic than the castle of Kenmore.

title: The works of Robert Burns: with an account of his life, and criticism on his writings.
author: Burns, Robert
snippet: He viewed " the highest hill which rise3 o'er the source of Dee :" and would have staid till " the passing spirit," had appeared, had we not resolved to reach Kenmore that night.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol
author: Trench, Francis.
snippet: He provided aresidence for Mr. Stuart, (of which I shallspeak by and by) and, as at Kenmore, w-herehe himself attends, so here he contributedlargely towards the erection of the newChurch, of which I have spoken before.

title: Scotland, its faith and its features; or, a Visit to Blair Athol

title: Miscellaneous Prose Works of Sir Walter Scott, Bart
author: Scott, Walter
snippet: Mackintosh thus effected his junction with the insurgents under Winton and Kenmore, and finallyshared at Preston the fate of the lord of the castle,which had for a time afforded him protection.
